comments.commentBody:
Howie, check it out. It's a pretty impressive list. Besides a number of athletes, as you mention, alumni include Aaron Copland, Man Ray Abraham Maslow and Mickey Marcus.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boys_High_School_(Brooklyn,_New_York)

This game was the Jets' to win after one quarter.

Their defense had the Seahawks on their heels, and quieted the famously noisy Seattle fans within the first fifteen minutes of play...

Even the second quarter was, by virtue of both teams' blunders, a draw. The Jets looked like they might be able to pull a stunning upset against a team previously unbeaten at home this season.

Then reality took over. Dropped passes, red zone INT, weak arm tackles, dumb penalties, bland play calling.

Season over.

See you next year.
Social Security has not contributed one penny to the deficit.

Listening to the Sunday talk shows, I got the distinct impression that there are some Republicans in the Senate that would go along with a tax increase for incomes over a million dollars, and also the closing of some loopholes for deductions like they were talking about during the campaign. You might see a deal that would include those concessions for raising the retirement age gradually for Social Security along with indexing the cap to inflation after an initial upward reset. The Administration needs to be willing to let the whole tax cut law expire and deal with the next congress if the Republicans start acting like they won't give up enough. It may take longer to work the whole fix out than by the end of the year in any case. President Obama and the Democratic Congressional leaders really need to play the endgame on this well, or the country will be facing another tough four years, even when you don't take into account the changing climate, and the economics of that will come into play whether we want to deal with it or not.

Global foreign policy is less about power and more about economics. State relations focus on large infra-structure cooperation like China's focus in Africa of building transportation and hydropower projects (railroads and dams) or the massive 114,000 km Trans-Asian Railway Network planned to extend from China to Europe with the participation of all the Asian countries in planning and financing the project.

America's foreign policy is still centered on gifts and power. The President has slowly begun moving the focus away from threat assessments and market access, to an engaged win-win approach that improves infra-structure to facilitate trade in consumer and critical resources and finished goods. Greater strides should be made in the second term. For instance, China's packaging industry is dependent upon American recycling for its materials; this business relationship, already quite large, could easily be expanded with coordination.

America's foreign policy establishment still enjoys discussions of personalities and power, of class and conflicts, of progress on rights. Across the world, foreign policy is breaking away from this traditional view to emphasize soft power.

Incidentally, soft power is one of America's oldest policy forms. England paid bounties to the colonies for materials such as indigo. England's Baring's bank financed the Louisiana Purchase. During the Civil War, European banks financed Confederate loans redeemable in cotton bales.
Don't you hate it when math beats politics?

Two things. First, you appear to not really understand the method being used by Silver and some of the others who are statistically aggregating polls. Silver doesn't just take a bunch of poll results and average them all together (Real Clear Politics does do that, however). The polls he uses are weighted based on past performance and many other factors, which is intended to minimize the detrimental effect you mention (of outlying data points) along with other distortions.

Second, his approach appears to work very well, having been tested on many different elections over multiple election cycles. He's obviously not "timid" (he's not even a pollster, by the way) in his use of multiple sources of polling data, and he is the one who has risen to the top, contrary to your hypothesized scenario.

I suppose you could be arguing that he's just been lucky, but I think you'd have a big statistical problem to overcome yourself with that suggestion.

IMHO

I'm really not sure what you're hoping to accomplish. An appeal to the romantic over the coldly logical? You're not really offering any better argument in these posts other than a passionately scornful "well math can't describe love, or kittens, so to heck with math!"

Le math, c'est moi. Le opinion publique c'est moi aussi.

I realize for the "progressives," Nate Silver is unassailable now and math is the new black and impositions of statistics on the psychology of political life is now unstoppable.

However, along the way on the numbers crunching, there are political decisions made along the way that are then unchallenged as such and become mere "math" and "infallible".

For example, the political decision to average all the pollsters' polls, and the political (cynical) belief that they engage in herding. Well, maybe they do, maybe they don't. Do we have old-fashioned investigative journalistic shoe-leather reporting on that to really bolster that assumption?

Oh, let's assume it's true -- can't challenge "math" now can we! Well, why are we averaging what might be really big spreads. In a public school, the teacher will drop out the test mark that is very low compared to others because it's not typical of the child's performance, so as not to drag down their mark. In other settings this is how things are averaged out. So in this setting, the pollster who has 60 polls that might have very different results might be punished just for having a lot of polls. The more timid pollster with only one poll could rise to the top. Indeed, the possible bias in this list is that it appears that those companies with more polls do worse when the averaging punishment is wielded on them than those companies that only had a few polls.

How have the deficit scolds been wrong? First, they have repeatedly claimed that deficits would cause hyperinflation. There has been very low inflation and very low interest rates. Second, the deficit scolds have been in charge in Europe, where the hangover from the recession lingers far worse than in the US. England has entered a second recession despite adopting severe austerity measures. By contrast China adopted the boldest expansionary policy and its economy rebounded fastest of all.
I'm sorry, but when before was President Obama "returned...to office," and when then did he metaphorically face-slap his constituents? The clock is ticking as you scramble for an answer....

"It's been well-demonstrated, time and time again, that if anybody knows how to face-slap the people who returned him to office, it's President Obama."

All this in under a week? Time & time again? Excuse me, but your attitude is showing.

If appointing a deficit scold is indeed a slap in the face to the people who returned President Obama to office (and of course it is), then look for a deficit scold, perhaps Erskine Bowles, to be appointed. It's been well-demonstrated, time and time again, that if anybody knows how to face-slap the people who returned him to office, it's President Obama.
The answers to all of your questions, Richard, can be found on Paul's blog, Conscience of a Liberal. I highly recommend you start reading circa November 2008. All will become crystal clear!
Obama just gave a speech on Friday in which he said a tax raise on the wealthy (really the repeal of the Bush tax cut) had to be part of the "fiscal cliff" negotiations.
Perhaps he could also "send a signal" by appointing Paul Ryan to the Ambassadorship of Libya ..?

Well said. I hope Obama listens and sends a signal he's listening by appointing someone like Sheila Bair to Treasury, not Erskine Bowles. This will be the a litmus test for the president as to whether he's one of the deficit scolds, or not. So far, he's given us no indictation that he's retreating from the deficit centric position of his first term.
Not sure how ironic this is meant to be, but it certainly comes across as lovely satire to me.  After all, those "crushing" deficits presaged the greatest economic boom in American history, no?

And they did this with top marginal tax rates at 91% under Eisenhower and 70% under JFK! No millionaires  jumped out of windows in despair or packed up and left the US for the Bahamas or Caymans. Instead of paying those rates, they reinvested their money in THIS country, in their businesses, in higher wages for their employees, in new equipment and in research and development. Amazing. Wonder where those patriots went?
Hope you're kidding, no comparison.

I'm starting to feel a little jealous that nobody ever worried about the WW2 debt they saddled my generation with. Nobody even mentioned it. They did talk about how great the GI Bill was, how great the new interstate highway system was going to be (as long as you didn't get stuck on a bumper-to-bumper 20 mile detour on a dirt road as it was being built). There was a lot of talk about how awful the great depression was and lots about atomic WW3 with the Commies, who meanwhile tended to hide under rugs in the State Dept, but nothing about that deficit that was roughly twice the size of this one (relative to GDP). As a result, none of us ever noticed our terrible burden. And now it's apparently insignificant.

This is just not fair.
Brilliance, at its best. "Steering the discourse of the fiscal cliff," great writing. "Defective worldview," great phrase. Your clarity, coherence, and interplay are never never tedious!

Mr. Kristof's description of this tragic and horrifying murder points out the most extreme way the doctrine of "perpetual war" practiced by the US Government since at least 2001 has corrupted and poisoned this nation. But there are other ways. I would mention the adulation of the US military which reminds me of the veneration of "His Imperial Majesty's Soldiers and Sailors" in Japan during the Pacific War, which is the very antithesis of the role of the armed forces in a democratic society. Nowadays, anyone who dares criticize the military in any way is likely to be called a traitor, shouted down, mostly on the right but also sometimes by liberals. This is a very unhealthy situation.

When I was a kid, I watched "You'll never get rich" on TV, with Phil Silvers playing the larcenous Sgt. Bilko. Back in the 1950s, so many men had served in our old democratic armies, fighting in World War II and Korea, that audiences could easily identify with the antics of the Sergeant and his slapstick motor pool. But today, anything like "You'll never get rich" would be condemned as a slur on our "heroes."

On top of the tendency to venerate the military is the view of war as a kind of spectator sport, eagerly exploited by Hollywood. With computer graphics, blowing away terrorists can be fun. It's sad to me to see kids in my suburban neighborhood running around in camouflage, carrying plastic M-16 replicas. I am not a pacifist, but . . . when will we ever learn?
I rarely agree with anything you post, but this baffles me too.

Note that 313 isn't even a possible configuration.

The average of 332 and 303 is 313. In the thousands of simulations i.e. the "Electoral Vote Distribution" in the side bar that Nate ran, he consistently had 332 and 303 appear as likely outcomes.
So true.  My 3 grown children & spouses are cell-only households and have been for > 5 years.  Just anecdotal, but still relevent.

The Democratic party, via Clinton's passage of nafta and deregulation of the financial "industry," has interest in cultural issues like gay marriage because such support does not interfere with capitalist evisceration of the middle-class. The report you cite showing growth at the top and bottom is directly related now to the function of universities: the top schools produce the IP attorneys and software whizzes, while universities like Cal State produce the public school teachers who finish in the bottom third of their graduating class.  The universities are now 70% part-time labor--not a democrat opposed this thirty-year process.  So what is actually happening is the two parties continue to compete for decisive segments of those who vote (52% of eligible voters), while the economic processes continue.  There is going to be hell to pay for this, and not in some distant future.

and yet, curiously, economic growth for all citizens increases under democratic administrations, as does job growth. reagan et al proclaimed that deficits don't matter and promptly increased deficits greatly. it was under the democratic clinton administration that the budget ran a surplus, a first in memory. trickle down voodoo economic policy may benefit a small percentage of the business class, but jfk, another democratic leader, was right to posit that a rising tide floats ALL boats.

Did you notice that he wrote that back on October 13th? Why don't you ask him if he has updated it since.

'Nuff said.

I think it's important to understand that the Electoral Vote prediction at the top of 538's graphs, is (if I've been following along correctly) an average of the results of the simulations performed by the 538 Model. It will never be exactly what the electoral college comes out to be. Of all of the simulations run that day, Obama's results AVERAGED OUT to 313 EV for Obama.

However, if you look at two other graphs: that of the national popular average, and the state by state predictions, the model was very accurate. The electoral map itself is dead on. This map and the real-life electoral college are ultimately binary in nature: regardless of how close a state's popular vote is, all of its EVs go to one candidate or the other. If the electoral PREDICTION at the top of the graphs was derived by counting up the electoral votes in a pure red or blue (binary), fashion based on the projected winner of each state, then it would of course have been as accurate as Nate's electoral map.

Consider the result of running 25001 election simulations with a "50.3%-D" Florida (whereby Obama only wins FLA 50.3% of the time, and with likewise percentage based wins in other states) and it becomes easier to understand the 313-O electoral prediction. When you average all of those simulations, Obama doesn't always win Florida, and therefore the average is less than the actual Electoral College result.

+1 everything puzzler said.

I also would point out that this Banking comparison is horribly naive, and from people who just don't get how banks operate. There is an ENORMOUS amount of fraud that occurs in banking every single day, and the banks are perfectly happy with it. As long as the bank is profitable, and the cost of preventing the fraud is lower than the cost of just making the customer whole they would rather let the fraud go through and report it to the FBI (thereby offloading the cost of enforcement and recovery on the general public).

If Banks had to provide guarantees against fraud equal to what we expect for elections they would go bankrupt extremely quickly.

Yes, if Rubio had been tapped, things would be different. And if a horse had stripes, it would be a zebra.

That is to say, I think the campaigns themselves would have been different, and I don't know whether Denver and the VP debate would have happened (because Obama wouldn't have been as complacent, because Romney wouldn't have taken a gamble on the House Republican budget plan, so on and so forth). And remember - not so long ago, Sarah Palin was regarded as the relatively prudent governor of a small, but energy-rich state. (Rubio isn't a Palin, but he hasn't been on Capitol Hill nearly as long as Paul Ryan.)

Right. It cuts to the core of what he was supposedly offering the electorate as a competent manager and technocrat. It boggles the mind. I thought he was staying positive for the troops and to help out down ballot, but that he actually was stuck in the same echo chamber as his most low information base voter is stunning.
Well, Minneapolis is not a State, anyway ... a great city, but not a State.

I'm on the Do Not Call List - so I've never been contacted by a pollster, which I would love to be! I didn't even see the Google poll. I highly recommend the Do Not Call List to avoid telemarketers - you can even sign your mobile phone numbers up.

According to something I read (a link on the Gallup accuracy post by Nate), 90% of Gallup likely voters end up voting and 50% of Gallup registered, but not likely, voters end up voting.  So if you only look at likely voters, and there is a significant difference between your registered voters and your likely voters, you're going to get the number wrong.
